Title:
Multiple origins of endophytes and the evolution of pyrophily
in the Pezizomycetes
Abstract:
The Pezizomycetes is an early diverged class in Ascomycota
with high taxonomic diversity and a wide range of ecological modes.
Endophytes are fungi inhabiting in healthy leaves without causing
diseases, and they are present in all plant species examined thus far.
They exhibit high diversity from tropical to arctic regions. The
diversification of this highly diverse functional group of symbionts has
not been studied thoroughly. Many factors can trigger biological
diversification, and environmental change is a common selection pressure
for evolution. The Pezizomycetes are known for containing some famous
pyrophilous taxa, and a previous study shows endophytes in fire-affected
area are dominated by Pezizomycetes. Whether these endophytes are
related to the pyrophilous fungi in this class is unclear. To understand
the diversification of different ecological forms and the relationships
of endophytic lifestyles to pyrophily, we used cumulative supermatrix
approach to infer phylogenetic relationships in the Pezizomycetes. Our
analyses containing 545 taxa and provided the basis for estimating
ancestral states of ecological forms and pyrophily using a maximum
likelihood approach. We found endophytes arose multiple times in
Pezizomycetes and were derived variously from saprotrophic or
ectomycorrhizal fungi. Some endophytic clades evolved early in
Pezizomycetes and have diversified over relatively long timeframes. The
diversification of pyrophilous fungi happened sparsely in multiple
lineages, and endophytes that are common after wildfire are not
descended from pyrophilous fungi, but from ecologically distinct fungi
which might compete inside the plants after colonization. Overall this
study provides insight in understanding the evolution and
diversification of endophytes.
